acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 48 hours LC50=0.013mg/L of the crustacea (Ceriodaphnia) (ECETOC TR91, 2003).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 195mg/kg calculated from the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 430mg/kg, 529mg/kg, 210mg/kg and 175mg/kg (ECETOC TR33 1989)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category K (as nickel compounds) by NTP (2005) and Category 1 (as nickel compounds) by IARC (1990).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since acute toxicity was Category 1 and it was a metallic compound, and since an underwater action and bio-accumulation were unknown, it was classified into Category 1.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available.

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on negative data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests (dominant lethal tests) and the absence of data on germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo and germ cell genotoxicity tests in vivo, and positive data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (chromosome aberration tests), described in IARC 49 (1990), EHC 108 (1991), ECETOC 33 (1989) and ATSDR (2005).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though being inorganic compounds containing chlorine

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the evidence of adverse effects on the reproductive function of parental animals and pup development, described in ATSDR (2005), IARC 49 (1990) and EHC 108 (1991). As for the reproductive/developmental toxicity of water-soluble inorganic nickel compounds, refer to "ID453, Nickel Sulfate, CAS: 7786-81-4."

respiratory_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause allergy or asthma symptoms or breathing difficulties if inhaled
respiratory_sensitizer.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as a Respiratory Sensitizing Substance by DFG (MAK/BAT (2005)) and "Respiratory Sensitizing Substance: Group 2" (as nickel compounds) according to the Recommendation on Occupational Exposure Limits for Chemical Substances (Japan Society for Occupational Health (2005)).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in EHC 108 (1991): "When aqueous solutions of nickel chloride were applied to the back, the threshold concentrations for irritancy were 1% with occlusion and 10% without occlusion." Also based on the evidence of skin irritation in humans (though the severity of the effects is unknown).

skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
skin_sensitizer.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as a Skin Sensitizing Substance by DFG (MAK/BAT (2005)) and "Skin Sensitizing Substance: Group 1" (as nickel compounds) according to the Recommendation on Occupational Exposure Limits for Chemical Substances (Japan Society for Occupational Health (2005)).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (kidney, respiratory system, testis)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale:
Based on the human evidence including "elevated urinary beta2-microglobulin levels" (ATSDR (2005)) and the evidence from animal studies including "hyperplasia of the bronchial epithelium, marked reduction of seminiferous tubule diameter" (ATSDR (2005)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.
Chronic exposure to nickel and its compounds may produce respiratory irritation and degeneration in humans even at doses close to occupational exposure limits. Prolonged exposure to high concentrations is likely to result in the fibroid lung (ECETOC TR33 (1989)).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (central nervous system)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale:
Based on the human evidence including "nausea, abdominal spasm, diarrhea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, debility and myalgia" (ATSDR (2005)).  
The acute toxicity of nickel compounds manifests in humans as "nausea, diarrhea, dizziness, headache" (ECETOC TR33 (1989)).
